titleStmt.title: James L. Turman to James F. Robinson
CWG4163

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: To his excellency James F Robinson Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky -- your petetioner states that at the last Term of the ^Boyd^ Circuit Court (April 1863) he was fined fifty dollars ($50) for selling Liqour to an infant -- ^towit^ Gobble Burgess -- he says that Burges was a candidate for the office of Mayor was as he learned ^since^ under 21 years of age barely had been doing business for some time for himself your petitioner being a Lisensed Tavern Keeper in Boyd County -- did let said Burgess have some Liquor to treat his friends as he said -- that he did not know that he was violating the Law -- said Burgess was an inteligent sober man and not doubting his being of age -- he prays your excellency to remit the fine yours & c

I George Burgess of Boyd county -- states that Goble Burgess is his son -- that he was well grown & had been doing business for himself that Turman is his neighbour that he had permitted said son of his to trade with Turman -- he was candidate as represented by Turman -- He states his son is sober -- ^& was going on 21 years old out of his 20th I think -- ^ He asks that the fine may be remitted against Turman believing in this instance and satisfied that Turman would do his son no injury -- & wasviolated the Law unintentionally this 4th day of may 1863.

we the undersign recommend the case of James L Turman as stated in thehis petitionr to be such that the executive should interfere and remit
the fine assessed
His Excellency the Governor of Kentucky

I was acting judge of the Boyd Circuit Court, at the time of the rendition of the judgment against The petitioner Turman and heard the evidence I am satisfied that Turman did not knowingly violate the Law, he supposed Gobel Burgess was in his majority.

Jas L. Turman
Catlettsburg
Boyd County
Kentucky --

James L Turman
to } Petition for Release fine
Gov,, of Kentucky

Boyd Cir Ct
$50 --
Jas L Turman
Remitted 4th Sept 1863
